meanings.def: a thick sweet substance made by boiling fruit with sugar, often sold in jars and spread on bread
examples: strawberry jam
a jar/pot of jam
recipes for jams and preserves
(British English) a jam doughnut

meanings.def: a situation in which it is difficult or impossible to move because there are so many people or vehicles in one particular place
examples: The bus was delayed in a five-mile jam.
As fans rushed to leave, jams formed at all the exits.
We were stuck in a jam for an hour.

meanings.def: a situation in which a machine does not work because something is stuck in one position
examples: There's a paper jam in the photocopier.

meanings.def: used by the media to describe people who do not have much money to live on (the abbreviation for just about managing)
examples: JAMs may be in work, but are struggling to pay for essentials such as food, heating or rent.

meanings.def: to be in a difficult situation
good things that are promised for the future but never happen
examples: They refused to settle for a promise of jam tomorrow.

meanings.def: money that is earned very easily, for something that needs little effort
examples: The job only took about an hour—it was money for jam.

idioms.def: to be in a difficult situation
good things that are promised for the future but never happen
examples: They refused to settle for a promise of jam tomorrow.

idioms.def: money that is earned very easily, for something that needs little effort
examples: The job only took about an hour—it was money for jam.

meanings.def: to push something somewhere with a lot of force
examples: He jammed his fingers in his ears.
A stool had been jammed against the door.

meanings.def: to become unable to move or work; to make something do this
examples: jam (up) The photocopier keeps jamming up.
jam something (up) There's a loose part that keeps jamming the mechanism.
+ adj. The valve has jammed shut.
jam something + adj. He jammed the door open with a piece of wood.
The traffic was jammed solid in the city centre.

meanings.def: to put somebody/something into a small space where there is very little room to move
examples: be jammed + adv./prep. Six of us were jammed into one small car.
We were jammed together like sardines in a can.
The cupboards were jammed full of old newspapers.
+ adv./prep. Nearly 1 000 students jammed into the hall.
The room is jammed tight with furniture.
The airport was jammed with people trying to arrange flights.
The streets were completely jammed with traffic.

meanings.def: to fill something with a large number of people or things so that it is unable to function as it should
examples: Viewers jammed the switchboard with complaints.
The traffic will just jam up our village.
People constantly jammed the street.

meanings.def: to send out radio signals to prevent another radio broadcast from being heard
to play music with other musicians in an informal way without preparing or practising first
to operate the brakes on a vehicle suddenly and with force
examples: The car skidded as he jammed on the brakes.

idioms.idiom: jam on the brake(s) | jam the brake(s) on
idioms.def: to operate the brakes on a vehicle suddenly and with force
examples: The car skidded as he jammed on the brakes.
